Dear Mr. Chipperfield:

We have received at this office your completed pioneer questionnaires, No's 2 - 6, together with additional information regarding the Hubbard Rural Telephone Company, the letter written by Mr. Reginald Gwinne, Grenfell, Feb. 27, 1896, and the Union Bank of Canada pass book issued to your father, Samuel Chipperfield.

We wish to express our appreciation for the time you have taken in preparing such careful replies to the questions asked. Your material will be preserved in this office as a permanent record of your family and the districts with which they were associated. Such material is made available as the occasion arises to students and writers of Saskatchewan history.

I regret that I was unable to see you when you were in the hospital here earlier in the year, but I trust that your health is now much improved. I hope to be able to fulfill my promise to call on you when next official duties may call me to Prince Albert.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

(Allan R. Turner,
Acting Assistant Provincial Archivist.)

Dear Sir:

A few days ago I sent in my report but did not have the information about the Hubbard Rural Telephone Company Limited and the following is the information we have received:

The first meeting to organize was April 21st, 1916 when officers were elected then May 2nd 1916 a meeting was held, a resolution passed that the capital of the company be $200.00, 60 shares of $5.00 each. On August 5th, 1916 the contract was let to R.C. Barwick Company.

I am also enclosing in connection with my report letter written by hand by Mr. Reginald Gwinne Deputy Sheriff of the Judicial District of East of Assiniboia. The letter was written from Grenfell N.W.T. on the 27th day of February, 1896 or 58 years ago. You will note that the Deputy Sheriff states that the cost of sending a man from Frenfell by train than by stage to Chickney a district from about 24 miles and then return for a fee of $5.00. It would not be possible to get a man today for less than $25.00.

We are also enclosing a Union Bank of Canada Indian Head Pass Book, Folio No. 908 dated first deposit April 17th, 1900 and the account was closed out on October 21st of the same year. This was a book in favor of my Father Samuel Chipperfield, Chickney, Saskatchewan.

Yours very truly,

SC/FP

The Mayor of Lemberg,
Lemberg, Sask.

Dear Friend:

Many thanks for the kind invitation sent to Mrs. Chipperfield and myself to attend your Old Timer's Banquet on the 29th instant.

As we are both old timers Mrs. Chipperfield at Lorlie and myself at Chickney we would have enjoyed the occasion very much. However, we are not able to attend as our eldest son Dr. Lawrence S. Chipperfield of New Westminster, British Columbia is arriving the next day by air to Saskatoon and we have arranged to meet him there by car and he will spend four days with us here.

We may say for your information that Mrs. Chipperfield arrived in Saskatchewan in May 1882, she came as an infant with her family. They came with ox team by wagons from Brandon and it took them four weeks to make the trip. The homestead her father obtained at the time is only about one mile from the present village of Lorlie. Mrs. Chipperfield lived on the farm until our marriage in 1907.

The writer came from Essex England in May 1883 and my father entered for his homestead on May 31st, 1883. This homestead was only a few miles west of Lemberg. He put up a tent on the farm which we lived in until about the 15th of November, by that time he had erected a log house with a sod roof. He had not had any experience in England building with logs so he had help from Mr. W.R. Motherwell who was afterwards the Minister of Agriculture for Saskatchewan and afterwards for the Dominion. In checking over one of my father's diaries, in October 1883 there was an entry of about $12.00 paid to Mr. Motherwell as labor on the house. In our trip from England, my father, mother, sister and myself got off the train at Indian Head and were treated very kindly by a family named Liggettes, the two families have been friends ever since.

In 1887 my father applied and obtained a Post Office at his farm home and was named Chickney after his old home in England. Later on a committee applied for a public school which was obtained and the following were the first trustees: Chairman, Samuel Chipperfield; Secretary, Henry Dixon; Treasurer, Mr. A.B. Ferrier. My father for a short time was a local J.P. He was also associated with the late John Teece and William Dixon in conducting religious services in some of the homes in the Chickney district.

About eighteen years after arrival the writer conducted a general store on a portion of land that belonged to my father's homestead, later opened a branch at Lemberg which was sold to Mr. Henry Aldous. In 1907 the writer moved to Kelowna and in December 1908 moved to Hubbard. We conducted a general store and Real Estate business there and in later years the writer's two sons Eric and Jim were associated with myself in the store business. In 1948 all our interest in Hubbard was sold. Eric and Jim bought a business in Minnedosa, Manitoba and the writer moved to Prince Albert and is now conducting a Real Estate and Insurance business.
The Mayor of Lemberg,
Lemberg, Sask.

Dear Friend:

Many thanks for the kind invitation sent to Mrs. Chipperfield and myself to attend your Old Times' Banquet on the 29th instant.

We are both old timers, Mrs. Chipperfield at Lemberg and myself at Chitchev. We would have enjoyed the occasion very much. However, we are not able to attend as our eldest son Dr. Lawrence S. Chipperfield of New Westminster, British Columbia is arriving the next day by air to Saskatoon and we have arranged to meet him there by car and he will spend four days with us here.

We may say for your information that Mrs. Chipperfield arrived in Saskatchewan in May 1852, she came as an infant with her family. They came with ox team by various from Brandon and it took them four weeks to make the trip. The homestead her father obtained at the time is only about one mile from the present village of Lemberg. Mrs. Chipperfield lived on the farm until our marriage in 1907.

The writer came from Baron England in May 1853 and my father entered for his homestead on May 31st, 1853. This homestead was only a few miles west of Lemberg. He put up a tent on the farm which he lived in until about the 15th of November, by that time he had erected a log house with a sod roof. He had not had any experience in building with logs so he had help from Mr. R. Northover who was afterwards the Minister of Agriculture for Saskatchewan and afterwards the Hon. A.E. Forrester. My father for a short time was a local U.T.F. He was also associated with the late John Teede and William Dixon in conducting religious services in some of the homes in the Chitchev district.

In 1887 my father applied and obtained a Post Office at his farm house and was named Chitchev after his old home in England. Later on a committee applied for a public school which was obtained and the following were the first trustees: Chairmen, Samuel Chipperfield; Secretary, Henry Macdonald; Treasurer, Mr. A.E. Forrester. My father for a short time was a local U.T.F. He was also associated with the late John Teede and William Dixon in conducting religious services in some of the homes in the Chitchev district.

About eighteen years after arrival the writer conducted a general store on a portion of land that belonged to my father's homestead. Later he opened a branch at Lemberg which was sold to Mr. Henry Allman. In 1907 the writer moved to Lemberg and in December 1908 moved to Hubbard. We conducted a general store and hall for the business there and in later years the writer's two sons Kyle and Jim were associated with myself in the store business. In 1948 all our interest in Hubbard was sold. Kyle and Jim bought a business in Minnedosa, Manitoba and the writer moved to Prince Albert and is now conducting a Real Estate and Insurance business.
We had six sons; Lawrence Samuel the eldest is a Medical Doctor at New Westminster, British Columbia, this year he was elected President of the College of Physicians and Surgeons for the Province of British Columbia; our second son John Norman died when he was 25, if he could have gone to University one more year he would have had his degree; our third son Eric Sydney as I stated before in Minnedosa, Manitoba; Donald Victor is a Medical Doctor in Prince Albert; James Hubert in addition to his share of business in Minnedosa has been Mayor of the town since 1951, he is also the President of the association of Urban Municipalities for the Province of Manitoba; Gordon Wesley is a Medical Doctor at Taber, Alberta.

We wish to take this opportunity of wishing all our old friends in your district a very happy and prosperous future.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Per

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of caution to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire in pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences but may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces nor the answers. If there is any surplus space on a sheet, please fill it in. Don't hesitate to give details or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Some of our relatives thought we were making a good move.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences).

One of my first recollections was the time I helped my father locate and enter for his homestead. The S.M.A. 16-2-10-2 and he also secured a preemption on the S.M.A. 16-2-10-2 homestead section. He had the use of this until I became 18 years of age when I obtained it as my homestead.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Indian Head, Sask. We stayed there about a week while my father located and entered for his homestead. The S.M.A. 16-2-10-2 and he also secured a preemption on the S.M.A. 16-2-10-2 homestead section. He had the use of this until I became 18 years of age when I obtained it as my homestead.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

The place had no name at the time we located but my father obtained a Post Office at his farm house in 1897 and he named it after himself. Since coming to Saskatchewan, I have lived at various places in the province of Saskatchewan. The Post Office and all other services have been moved to either Athabasca or Lemberg.

17. Mention any other places you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I lived at Athabasca, Hubberton and Prince Albert.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Too young before I came. Halfway on my third year until I was 17, after that time and then I managed a store at Chipman for two years, then bought it and operated it until the old Highway Line came in. Later I bought a store at Falsona, Alberta and operated it until 1902. I then sold out to my son and I operated a real estate and insurance business in the Chipmanfield Land Company at Hubberton. In 1907 I moved to Prince Albert and in 1909 opened a Real Estate and Insurance Office in the City of Prince Albert which I still conduct.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Some of our relatives of course did not like the idea of us going so far away from them, but others thought we were making a good move.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Steamer to Quebec and C.P. and connecting railways to Indian Head, Sask.

14. What accidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences.)

One of my first recollections was the fire and half breed Indians, as I grew older I remember the Indians helping me do the chores, such as bucking wood and carrying water in the summer, feeding pigs and calves and also helping in the garden, when I got old enough I helped in the plowing and some other farm work. I lost the farm when I was 17½ to take up a business career.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Indian Head, Sask. We stayed there about a week while my father located and entered for his homestead. The S.M. 17-2-10-6 end he also staked on a preemption of the S.E.¼ of the northwest quarter. He had the use of this until I became 18 years of age when I obtained it by homestead.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

The place had no name at the time we landed but my father obtained a Post Office at his farm house in 1897 and he named it "Indian Head" since coming to Saskatchewan.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Canada.

I lived at Lumsden, Lumbard and Prince Albert.

(As my son says that Old Indian is now represented by the Okotoks Public School No. 45 in the province of Saskatchewan. The Post Office and all other services have been moved to either Abernathy or Lumbard.)

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Too young before I came, helping on my father's farm until I was 17½ after that I operated at until the railway line came in. I later took General Store & Alternately until 1907 then sold it and opened up a store at Lumsden, Lumbard and in 1908 moved to Lumbard and operated a store until 1911. Then I then sold out to my Son and I operated a Real Estate and Insurance Business known as the Chipperfield Land Company at Lumbard. In 1927 I moved to Prince Albert and in 1949 opened a Real Estate and Insurance Office in the City of Prince Albert which I am still conducting, this is know as the Chipperfield Agencies.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving?

Our neighbor Mr. Wells Johnson who came to Canada in 1885 and took up a homestead on the North part of the same section as my father, after getting his title he sold his quarter to a neighbor who went to college and became an Anglican minister. He afterward became a Presbyterian minister of Moore, Ontario, where he died in 1924.

There was a congregation of about seventy-five people before he left; there was a congregation quarter of a mile down the road. Mr. W. J. Harrow who homesteaded on the other side of the road, bought the Johnson quarter and established an Anglican church there.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

No, we only had one crop failure and that was in 1937.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

At Abernethy I was Sec. Treas. for the Presbyterian Church, at Hubbard was Chairman of the Board of Directors of the United Church, and President of the Board of Directors of the Liberal Organization. Overseer of the Overlook Home for fifteen years, and on the Council of the Town Hall for thirty years.

Hospital Board until May 1st, 1929 when I moved to Prince Albert, I was an elder in the United Church of Abernethy, and a member of the United Church of Prince Albert.

In 1929 we purchased the Abernethy property of the United Church of the United Church of Canada, and in 1930 we presented the building to the town of Abernethy.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "firsts" to have or do something in the district mention it here, giving dates wherever possible (such as owning the first automobile, combining organizing the first lodge, etc.).

My automobile was one of the first in public use. I helped organize the Red Cross chapter of the first World War, also organized the first Sunday School. Mrs. Chipperfield was one of the first Trustees of the Hubbard School.
